title: Man who had routine hernia operation died after suffering a stroke the next day
text:

A man who underwent a routine hernia operation tragically died after suffering a stroke the following day.

An inquest was told the timing of 62-year-old Peter Heard's stroke was a coincidence - although it was also described as 'suspicious'.

Despite the family’s solicitor requesting a narrative verdict, the coroner concluded that Mr Heard died from natural causes.

But his widow Anne Heard, of Ottery St Mary in Devon, told coroner Andrew Cox that she did not want his sympathy concerning her late husband.

She then walked out of the inquest into his death while declaring “I will take this matter further,” according to Devon Live.

The inquest in Truro, where Devon coroner Mr Cox is now overseeing cases, heard today that Mr Heard, a fit and active man, had elective surgery on a hernia at Heavitree Hospital in Exeter on July 19, 2018.

His blood pressure at the time of the operation was well within the safe limit and was checked before, during and after the procedure.

All risks associated with the routine operation were described to Mr Heard, although not any risk of death which was believed to be too small.

He was reassured and happy to proceed.

(Image: Google)

The procedure went smoothly and the anaesthetist was happy that nothing occurred which could have played a part in his stroke the next day.

The inquest heard that Mr Heard was keen to return home and sleep in his own bed.

In the early morning of the next day he was found collapsed downstairs in his home.

He was admitted to the Royal Devon and Exeter Hospital suffering from a stroke.

It was decided that in his best interests he should be transferred to Derriford Hospital in Plymouth where a thrombectomy would be performed to retrieve a clot from his brain.

Unfortunately, the procedure was not successful and the operation was terminated.

Over the next few days he was no longer able to respond with his eyes or verbally, and his brain function deteriorated.

He died on July 23.

Mr Cox read a statement from Mr Heard’s son Daniel which questioned whether the hernia operation caused or contributed to the clot which killed his father.

Consultant Mr Ivaylo Tzvetkov said that only one in 5,000 patients suffer such a complication following a hernia operation.

He believed the timing was a coincidence and felt the surgery did not play a part in the clot developing.

Pathologist Dr David Hilton was unable to say if the procedure was a factor, but in 25 years’ experience as a consultant he had never seen a previous case where a hernia operation had caused a stroke.

However, he did say that the timing was suspicious.

(Image: Google)

Mr Cox said: “The nub of the issue is whether the procedure on July 19 caused the clot that developed on July 20 and led to Mr Heard’s death.

“Patients do not expect to die after going for elective surgery and a hernia is a routine procedure, but it is the case that all surgery carries with it a risk.

“The circumstances of someone dying as a result of this procedure are extremely rare.

“I feel Mrs Heard’s husband was desperately unlucky, which I am sure is no consolation to Mrs Heard.”

She shook her head at this as she did while hearing much of the evidence during the inquest.

Mr Cox added: “While the timing is suspicious it’s not possible to say that the procedure caused the rupture and subsequent clot.”

Despite the family’s solicitor requesting a narrative verdict, Mr Cox concluded that Mr Heard died from natural causes.

After Mr Cox gave Mrs Heard his sympathy, she replied: “Don’t give me any sympathy. I’m going to take this further” before walking out of the inquest.

She didn’t want to say anything further to Devon Live following the hearing.
description: An inquest heard how a consultant believed the timing of Peter Heard's stroke to be a coincidence and felt the surgery did not play a part - however a coroner did describe the timing as 'suspicious'
